{{see also|Threatened sharks}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} [[File:Shark fins.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[NOAA]] agent counting [[confiscated]] shark fins]] [[File:Yokohama Chinese Medicine Shark fin large.jpg|thumb|right|Shark fins on display in a pharmacy in Yokohama, Japan]]
'''Shark finning''' is the act of removing [[Fish fin#Cartilaginous fishes|fins]] from [[shark]]s and discarding the rest of the shark. The sharks are often still alive when discarded, but without their fins.<ref>Schindler, D.E., Essington, T.E., Kitchell, J.F., Boggs, C. and Hilborn, R. (2002) [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/wol1/doi/10.1890/1051-0761(2002)012%5B0735:SATFIO%5D2.0.CO;2/abstract "Sharks and tunas: fisheries impacts on predators with contrasting life histories"]. ''Ecological Applications'', '''12''' (3): 735–748. {{doi|10.1890/1051-0761(2002)012[0735:SATFIO]2.0.CO;2}}</ref><ref name=Spiegel2000>Spiegel, J. (2000) [http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/bcic24&div=22&id=&page= "Even Jaws deserves to keep his fins: outlawing shark finning throughout global waters"]. ''Boston College International and Comparative Law Review'', '''24''' (2): 409–438.</ref><ref>Fowler, S., Séret, B. and Clarke, S. (2010) [http://66.112.194.141/shark_fin_report_final.pdf ''Shark fins in Europe: Implications for reforming the EU finning ban''], [[IUCN]] Shark Specialist Group.</ref> Unable to swim effectively, they sink to the bottom of the ocean and die of [[suffocation]] or are eaten by other predators. Shark finning at sea enables fishing vessels to increase profitability and increase the number of sharks harvested, as they only have to store and transport the fins, by far the most profitable part of the shark; the shark meat is bulky to transport.<ref name="Clarke2007">{{cite journal|last1=Clarke|first1=Shelley|last2=Milner-Gulland |first2=E.J.|last3=Bjorndal |first3=Trond |title=Social, Economic, and Regulatory Drivers of the Shark Fin Trade|journal=Marine Resource Economics|date=October 2007|volume=22|issue=3|pages=305–327|url=http://purl.umn.edu/47060|accessdate=3 April 2012|publisher=Marine Resources Foundation}}</ref> Some countries have banned this practice and require the whole shark to be brought back to port before removing the fins.
Shark finning increased since 1997 largely due to the increasing demand for shark fins for [[shark fin soup]] and traditional cures, particularly in China and its territories, and as a result of improved fishing technology and market economics. The [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]]'s Shark Specialist Group say that shark finning is widespread, and that "the rapidly expanding and largely unregulated shark fin trade represents one of the most serious threats to shark populations worldwide".<ref name="Buckley">{{cite book|last=Buckley|first=Louis|title=The End of the Line|year=2007|publisher=WildAid|page=21|url=http://wildaid.org/sites/default/files/resources/EndOfTheLine2007US.pdf|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111202162302/http://wildaid.org/sites/default/files/resources/EndOfTheLine2007US.pdf|archivedate=2 December 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Estimates of the global value of the shark fin trade range from US$540 million<ref name="Clarke2007" /> to US$1.2 billion (2007).<ref name="York2003"/> Shark fins are among the most expensive seafood products, commonly retailing at US$400 per kg.<ref name="Buckley" /> In the United States, where finning is prohibited, some buyers regard the [[whale shark]] and the [[basking shark]] as trophy species, and pay $10,000 to $20,000 for a fin.<ref name="NG02"> {{cite web |url= http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2002/09/0917_020917_sharks.html |title=Shark-Soup Boom Spurs Conservationist DNA Study |publisher=National Geographic |author= Bijal P. Trivedi |date=17 September 2002 |accessdate=3 April 2012 }}</ref>
The regulated global catch of sharks reported to the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] of the United Nations has been stable in recent years at an annual average just over 500,000 tonnes. Additional unregulated and unreported catches are thought to be common.<ref name=FAO2014>[http://www.fao.org/3/a-i3720e.pdf The State of World Fisheries and Aquaculture 2014] Page 17 and 124, [[FAO]], Rome. {{ISBN|978-92-5-108275-1}}.</ref>
==Process== Nearly every fin of a shark is targeted for harvest, as highlighted in the diagram. The primary and secondary [[dorsal fin]]s are removed from the top of the shark, plus its [[pectoral fins]], and, in a single cutting motion, the [[pelvic fin]], [[anal fin]], and bottom portion of its [[caudal fin]], or tail.<ref name=vannuccini>{{cite web |last=Vannuccini |first=S |year=1999 |title=Shark utilization, marketing and trade. FAO Fisheries Technical Paper. No. 389. Rome, FAO |url=http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/005/X3690E/x3690e0p.htm}}</ref>
Because the rest of the shark has little value relative to that of its fins, sharks are sometimes finned while fishing vessels are still at sea, and the finless and often still-living shark is thrown back into the sea to free space aboard the vessel.<ref name="WA"/> In legal contexts the use of the term "shark finning" can refer specifically to this practice of removing the fins from live sharks and discarding the carcass while still at sea.<ref name="fowler-seret" /> For these legal purposes the removal of fins on land during catch processing is not necessarily considered to be shark finning.<ref name="fowler-seret">Fowler, S. & Seret, B. (2010). Shark fins in Europe: implications for reforming the EU finning Ban. (Plymouth and Burnaby, BC: European Elasmobranch Association and IUCN Shark Specialist Group)</ref>
Shark species that are commonly finned are:<ref name=Spiegel2000 /><ref name=vannuccini />
[[File:Shark finning diagram.svg|thumb|300px|Highlights showing the typical targets of finning|alt=A diagram of a shark, with every fin highlighted in pink and drawn separated from its body, except for the top half of its tail]]
* [[Blacktip shark|Blacktip]] (''Carcharhinus limbatus'') * [[Blue shark|Blue]] (''Prionace glauca'') (a species of [[requiem shark]]) * [[Bull shark|Bull]] (''Carcharhinus leucas'') * [[Hammerhead shark|Hammerhead]] (family Sphyrnidae) * [[Porbeagle]] (''Lamna nasus'') (a species of [[Lamniformes|mackerel shark]]) * [[Shortfin mako shark|Mako]] (''Isurus oxyrinchus'') * [[Sandbar shark|Sandbar]] (''Carcharhinus plumbeus'') (a species of requiem shark) * [[Thresher shark|Thresher]] (family Alopiidae) * [[Tiger shark|Tiger]] (''Galeocerdo cuvier'') (a species of requiem shark) * [[Great white shark]] (''Carcharodon carcharias'')
==Impacts==
===On individual sharks=== [[File:Carcharias taurus in UShaka Sea World 1079-a.jpg|thumb|300px|right|The [[sand tiger shark]] is a large coastal shark that inhabits coastal waters worldwide. Its numbers have declined significantly, and it is now listed as a [[vulnerable species]] on the [[IUCN Red List]].<ref name=IUCNREDLIST>{{Cite journal | vauthors = Pollard D, Smith A | last-author-amp = yes | title = ''Carcharias taurus'' | journal = [[The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]] | volume = 2009 | page = e.T3854A10132481 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | date = 2009 | url = http://oldredlist.iucnredlist.org/details/3854/0 | doi = 10.2305/IUCN.UK.2009-2.RLTS.T3854A10132481.en | access-date = 15 January 2018}}</ref>]]
When sharks have been finned, they are likely to die from lack of oxygen because they are not able to move to filter the water through their gills, or are eaten by other fish that have found them defenseless at the bottom of the ocean. Though studies suggest that 73 million sharks are finned each year, scientists have noted that the numbers may actually be closer to the 100 million mark. Due to the fact that sharks do not mature and mate until they are approximately 30 years old, their reproduction rate is slow and cannot keep pace with the current mortality rate.<ref>http://dukespace.lib.duke.edu/dspace/bitstream/handle/10161/6890/Latchford_Lauren_MP_Final.pdf|{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Title = Conservation or culture? An analysis of shark finning in the united states| Author = Lauren Latchford| Year = 2013| accessdate = 27 April 2017</ref>
===On shark populations=== Some studies suggest 26 to 73 million sharks are harvested annually for fins. The annual median for the period from 1996 to 2000 was 38 million, which is nearly four times the number recorded by the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] (FAO) of the United Nations,<ref name="Clarke2006">{{cite journal|last1=Clarke|first1=Shelley C.|first2=Murdoch K. |last2=McAllister |first3=E. J.|last3=Milner-Gulland |first4=G. P. |last4=Kirkwood |first5=Catherine G. J. |last5=Michielsens |first6=David J. |last6=Agnew |first7=Ellen K. |last7=Pikitch|first8=Hideki |last8=Nakano |first9=Mahmood S. |last9=Shivji|year=2006|title=Global estimates of shark catches using trade records from commercial markets|journal=Ecology Letters |volume=9 |issue=10 |pages=1115–1126 |issn=1461-023X|doi=10.1111/j.1461-0248.2006.00968.x |ref=harv |pmid=16972875}}</ref> but considerably lower than the estimates of many conservationists.<ref name="NG06"> {{cite web |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2006/10/061012-shark-fin.html |title=38 Million Sharks Killed for Fins Annually, Experts Estimate |publisher=National Geographic |author=Nicholas Bakalar |date=12 October 2006 |accessdate=8 January 2007 }}</ref> It has been reported that the global shark catch in 2012 was 100 million.<ref name="BBC news">BBC (UK) news item transmitted 5 March 2013</ref>
Sharks have a [[r/K selection theory|K-selection]] life history, which means that they tend to grow slowly, reach maturity at a larger size and a later age, and have low reproductive rates.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pauly|first1=D.|first2=L. |last2=Biery|year=2012|title=A global review of species-specific shark-fin-to-body-mass ratios and relevant legislation|journal=Journal of Fish Biology |volume=80 |issue=5 |pages=1643–1677 |doi=10.1111/j.1095-8649.2011.03215.x |pmid=22497402}}</ref> These traits make them especially vulnerable to [[overfishing]] methods, such as shark finning. Recent studies suggest changes in abundance of [[apex predators]] may have cascading impacts on a variety of ecological processes.
Numbers of some shark species have dropped as much as 80% over the last 50 years.<ref name="LM2"> {{cite web |url = http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/sharks/InNews/critics2006.html |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071102230904/http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/sharks/InNews/critics2006.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2 November 2007 |title = Rising Demand For Fins Contributes To Decline in Shark Population, Critics Charge |author = Laura Marquez |publisher = ABC News |date = 30 October 2006 |accessdate = 8 January 2007 }}</ref> Some organizations claim that shark fishing or [[bycatch]] (the unintentional capture of species by other fisheries) is the reason for the decline in some species' populations and that the market for fins has very little impact – bycatch accounts for an estimated 50% of all sharks taken<ref name="WA" /> – others that the market for shark fin soup is the main reason for the decline.<ref name="LM2" />
===On other populations=== Sharks are apex predators and have extensive implications for marine systems an processes, particularly [[coral reefs]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Garla|first1=R. C.|first2=D. D. |last2=Chapman |first3=M. S.|last3=Shivji |first4=B. M. |last4=Wetherbee |first5=A. F. |last5=Amorim|year=2006|title=Habitat of juvenile Caribbean reef sharks, ''Carcharhinus perezi'', at two oceanic insular marine protected areas in the southwestern Atlantic Ocean: Fernando de Noronha Archipelago and Atol das Rocas, Brazil|journal=Fisheries Research |volume=81 |pages=236–241 |doi=10.1016/j.fishres.2006.07.003}}</ref> A report by [[WildAid]] on global threats to sharks further explains the importance of these animals.<ref name="Buckley"/>
Fins from the critically endangered [[sawfish]] (Pristidae) "are highly favored in Asian markets and are some of the most valuable shark fins".<ref>[http://www.nmfs.noaa.gov/pr/pdfs/recovery/smalltoothsawfish.pdf Recovery Plan for Smalltooth Sawfish (Pristis pectinata)]. National Marine Fisheries Service. 2009, Retrieved 18 March 2009.</ref> Sawfishes are now protected under the highest protection level of the [[Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species]] (CITES), Appendix I.<ref>{{cite news |first=Richard |last=Black |year=2007 |title=Sawfish protection acquires teeth |publisher=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/6740609.stm |accessdate=19 March 2009}}</ref>
==Vulnerability of sharks== On the [[IUCN Red List]] there are 39 species of [[elasmobranch]]es (sharks and rays) listed as threatened species ([[Critically endangered species|Critically Endangered]], [[Endangered species|Endangered]] or [[Vulnerable species|Vulnerable]]).<ref name="ST"> {{cite web |url = http://www.sharktrust.org/do_download.asp?did=26336 |title = List of endangered sharks |publisher = The Shark Trust |accessdate = 8 January 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928081734/http://www.sharktrust.org/do_download.asp?did=26336 |archivedate = 28 September 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=January 2012}}
In 2013, the [[Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora]] (CITES) listed the vulnerability of sharks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cites.org/eng/app/appendices.php|title=Appendices I, II and III|author=Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora|year=2013|accessdate=13 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cites.org/eng/app/index.php|title=The CITES Appendices|author=Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora|year=2013|accessdate=13 September 2013}}</ref>
Appendix I, which lists animals that are threatened with extinction, lists *Requiem sharks *Hammerhead sharks *Basking shark *Mackerel sharks *Whale shark{{citation needed|date=March 2017}}
Appendix II, which lists animals that are not necessarily now threatened with extinction but that may become so unless trade is closely controlled, lists * [[Basking shark]] (''Cetorhinus maximus'') * [[Great white shark]] (''Carcharodon carcharias'') * [[Whale shark]] (''Rhincodon typus'') A further five species are listed as of 2014 – * [[Scalloped hammerhead]] (''Sphyrna lewini'') * [[Great hammerhead shark]] (''Sphyrna mokarran'') * [[Smooth hammerhead]] (''Sphyrna zygaena'') * [[Porbeagle]] (''Lamna nasus'') * [[Oceanic whitetip shark]] (''Carcharhinus longimanus'')
==Opposition== [[File:Ban Sharing Finning BMD.jpg|thumb|left|A mural protesting shark finning in Wellington, New Zealand]] The crew of the [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society]] conservation vessel [[RV Ocean Warrior|RV ''Ocean warrior'']] witnessed and photographed industrial-scale finning within Costa Rica's [[Cocos Island National Park]] protected marine area.<ref name="RM1"> {{cite web |url=http://www.shark-info.ch/News/newsres.html?lang=e&keyword=Fins&num=161 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707002801/http://www.shark-info.ch/News/newsres.html?lang=e&keyword=Fins&num=161 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 July 2011 |title=Disaster off the coast of the Cocos Islands |publisher=Shark Info |accessdate=5 December 2007 }}</ref> The practice is featured in the documentary ''Sharks: Stewards of the Reef'', which contains footage from Western Australia and Central America and also examines shark finning's cultural, financial and ecological impacts. Underwater photographer Richard Merritt witnessed finning of living sharks in Indonesia where he saw immobile finless sharks lying on the sea bed still alive below the fishing boat.<ref name="RM2"> {{cite web |url = http://www.bluespheremedia.com/shark-conservation.html |title = Shark conservation |publisher = Blue Sphere Media |accessdate = 5 December 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080105103710/http://www.bluespheremedia.com/shark-conservation.html |archivedate = 5 January 2008 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Finning has been witnessed and filmed within a protected marine area in the Raja Ampat islands of Indonesia.<ref name="RM3"> {{cite web |url = http://misoolecoresort.com/newsJanuary2007.html |title = 16 January 2007: Encountering Shark Finners inside our Marine Protected Area |publisher = Misool Eco Resort |accessdate = 5 December 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080820005538/http://www.misoolecoresort.com/newsJanuary2007.html |archivedate = 20 August 2008 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Animal welfare]] groups vigorously oppose finning on perceived moral grounds and also because it is one cause for the rapid decline of global shark populations.<ref name="WA"> {{cite web |title=Sharks |publisher=WildAid |accessdate=6 January 2007 |url=http://www.wildaid.org/index.asp?CID=3&PID=352&SUBID=&TERID=490 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060521181303/http://www.wildaid.org/index.asp?CID=3&PID=352&SUBID=&TERID=490 |archivedate=21 May 2006 }}</ref>
Because of the lucrative profits and alleged size of the market, there are allegations of links to organized crime.<ref name="York2003"> {{cite web |url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/shark-soup/article1012780/ |title=Shark Soup |author=Geoffrey York |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date=27 August 2003 |accessdate=8 January 2007 }}</ref><ref name="iss"> {{cite web |url = http://www.iss.co.za/Pubs/Papers/48/48.html |title = Triad Societies and Chinese Organised Crime in South Africa |author = Peter Gastrow |year = 2001 |publisher = Institute for Security Studies |accessdate = 8 January 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110609171245/http://www.iss.co.za/Pubs/Papers/48/48.html |archivedate = 9 June 2011 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> Opponents also raise questions on the medical harm from the consumption of high levels of toxic mercury reportedly found in shark fins.
[[File:Ecuadorian fishing boat.jpg|thumb|right|Shark fin fishing boat off the [[Galapagos]], Ecuador|alt=Photo of single-masted boat at sea]] A third of fins imported to Hong Kong come from Europe.<ref name="SA">{{cite web|title=Shark fisheries and trade in Europe|publisher=Shark Alliance|accessdate=6 January 2007|url=http://www.sharkalliance.org/content.asp?did=23514}}</ref> Spain is by far the largest supplier, providing between 2,000 and 5,000 metric tons a year.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1406939.stm|title=EU faces shark fin ban call|publisher=BBC|date=25 June 2001|accessdate=8 January 2007}}</ref><ref name="G-stats">{{cite news|url=http://environment.guardian.co.uk/conservation/story/0,,1862110,00.html|title= Sharks pay high price as demand for fins soars|author=Ian Sample|publisher=The Guardian|date=31 August 2006|accessdate=8 January 2007 | location=London}}</ref> Norway supplies 39 metric tonnes, but Britain, France, Portugal and Italy are also major suppliers.<ref name="INDP2">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/growth-in-shark-fin-trade-could-lead-to-species-extinction-414086.html|title= Growth in shark fin trade could lead to species extinction|author=Steve Connor|publisher=The Independent|date=31 August 2006|accessdate=31 January 2011 | location=London}}</ref> Hong Kong handles at least 50% and possibly up to 80% of the world trade in shark fin, with the major suppliers being Europe, Taiwan, Indonesia, Singapore, United Arab Emirates, United States, Yemen, India, Japan, and Mexico.<ref name="SSG">{{cite web|url=http://www.flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/organizations/ssg/ssgfinstatementfinal2june.pdf|title=Shark Specialist Group Finning Statement|publisher=IUCN Shark Specialist Group|author=Sarah Fowler|author2=Dr John A Musick|last-author-amp=yes|date=2 June 2006|accessdate=8 January 2007}}</ref> According to Giam's article,<ref name="GCH"/> "Sharks are caught in virtually all parts of the world.... Despite the strongly declared objectives of the Fisheries Commission in Brussels, there are very few restrictions on fishing for sharks in European waters. The meat of [[Squaliformes|dogfish]]es, [[smoothhound]]s, [[cat shark]]s, [[skate (fish)|skates]] and [[Batoidea|rays]] is in high demand by European consumers.... The situation in Canada and the United States is similar: the [[blue shark]] is sought after as a sport fish while the porbeagle, mako and [[spiny dogfish]] are part of the commercial fishery.... The truth is this: Sharks will continue to be caught and killed on a wide scale by the more organized and sophisticated fishing nations. Targeting shark's fin soup will not stop this accidental catch. The fins from these catches will be thrown away or turned into animal feed and fertilizers if shark's fin soup is shunned." <!--not sure this is relevant, it is general ecosystem dynamics:Large-scale removal of sharks may severely unbalance the [[ecosystem]] of warm seas by allowing some species of large or middle-sized fish to multiply or grow bigger: for an example see [[grouper]].--> <!--another way to look at the reduced pressure is that it removes pressure on species that both humans and sharks prefer-->
In 2007, Canadian filmmaker and photographer [[Rob Stewart (filmmaker)|Rob Stewart]] created a film, ''[[Sharkwater]]'', which exposes the shark fin industry in detail. In March 2011, the VOA [[Special English]] service of the [[Voice of America]] broadcast a 15-minute science program on shark finning.
==Reporting== [[Image:Global shark catch.svg|thumb|230px|Global shark catch, since 1950. Source [http://www.fao.org/fishery/statistics/global-capture-production/query/en]|alt=Line graph showing the rapidly growing annual shark harvest]] According to Giam Choo Hoo – the longest serving member of [[CITES|The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora]] Animals Committee,<ref name="GCH" /> and a representative of the shark fin industry in Singapore<ref>{{cite news|last=Eilperin|first=Juliet|title=Is the shark fin ban culturally biased?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/blogpost/post/is-the-shark-fin-ban-culturally-biased/2012/02/21/gIQAbIj9SR_blog.html|accessdate=13 July 2013|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=22 February 2012|quote=Here's the catch: I interviewed Giam for my book [...] and he wears a few hats. While he does participate in the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), he's also a representative of the shark fin industry in Singapore.}}</ref> – "The perception that it is common practice to kill sharks for only their fins – and to cut them off whilst the sharks are still alive – is wrong.... The vast majority of fins in the market are taken from sharks after their death."<ref name="GCH"> {{cite news |url = http://www.iwmc.org/PDF/StraitsTPress.pdf |author = Giam Choo Hoo |title = Shark's fin soup – eat without guilt |date = 1 December 2006 |newspaper = The Straits Times |accessdate = 6 January 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070221165724/http://www.iwmc.org/PDF/StraitsTPress.pdf |archivedate = 21 February 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
However, researchers dispute this claim by pointing to the data: using a statistical analysis of shark fin industry trade data, a 2006 study estimated that between 26 and 73 million sharks are harvested each year worldwide.{{sfnp|Clarke|McAllister|Milner-Gulland|Kirkwood|2006|p=1119|ps=: "Estimates of the total number of sharks traded annually worldwide, based on all fin positions combined, ranged from 26 to 73 million... with an overall [[median]] of 38 million"}} That figure, when converted to shark [[biomass]], was three to four times higher than the catch recorded in [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] capture production statistics, the only global database of shark catches.{{sfnp|Clarke|McAllister|Milner-Gulland|Kirkwood|2006|p=1120|ps=: "Our median biomass estimate for the global shark fin trade based on all fin positions combined (1.70 million tonnes year<sup>−1</sup>) is more than four times higher than the midrange FAO-based figure (0.39 million tonnes), and nearly three times higher than the high FAO estimate (0.60 million tonnes year<sup>−1</sup>)"}} According to the researchers, this discrepancy "may be attributable to factors... such as unrecorded shark landings, shark biomass recorded in [non-specific] categories, and/or a high frequency of shark finning and carcass disposal at sea."{{sfnp|Clarke|McAllister|Milner-Gulland|Kirkwood|2006|p=1120}} Simply put, they say that the industry is either under-reporting the sharks taken annually, or is frequently engaging in the practice of finning.
==International restrictions== [[File:Shark fins Hong Kong.jpg|thumb|right|Fresh shark fins drying on a pavement in Hong Kong]] In 2013, 27 countries and the European Union had banned shark finning;<ref name="HSI" /> however, [[international waters]] are unregulated. International fishing authorities are considering banning shark fishing (and finning) in the Atlantic Ocean and [[Mediterranean Sea]]. Finning is banned in the Eastern [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]],<ref name="ENS"> {{cite web |url=http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/jun2005/2005-06-29-03.asp |title=Shark Finning Banned in Eastern Pacific Ocean |publisher=Environment News Service |date=9 June 2005 |accessdate=8 January 2007 }}</ref> but shark fishing and finning continues unabated in most of the Pacific and Indian Ocean.<ref name="WA"/> In countries such as Thailand and Singapore, public awareness advertisements on finning have reportedly reduced consumption by 25%.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}}
There are four main categories of restrictions, as follows: * Shark sanctuary (an area where shark fishing is entirely prohibited); * Areas where sharks must be landed with fins attached; * Areas where fin to body mass ratio-based regulations have been implemented; * Areas where shark product trade regulations exist.<ref>Biery L. and Pauly, D. (2012) A global review of species-specific shark-fin-to-body-mass ratios and relevant legislation, Journal of Fish Biology</ref>
===European Union=== Shark finning was prohibited in the EU in 2003 (Regulation (EC) No 1185/2003).<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2003:167:0001:0003:EN:PDF COUNCIL REGULATION (EC) No 1185/2003 of 26 June 2003 on the removal of fins of sharks on board vessels]</ref>
In November 2011, the [[European Commission|EC]] approved a rule that would require all EU-registered fishing boats to land only sharks which have retained all their fins. Because the legislation allowed fins to be removed on the boat and different body parts to be landed at different ports, the ban proved difficult to enforce. The EU Parliament's fisheries committee supported the EC's proposal to ban the separate landing of shark bodies and fins, however, the committee approved an amendment which allows fins to be removed on board a vessel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theparliament.com/latest-news/article/newsarticle/eu-parliament-urged-to-close-loopholes-in-shark-fin-legislation/|title=EU parliament urged to close 'loopholes' in shark fin legislation|author=Banks, M.|publisher=The Parliament.com|date=25 September 2012|accessdate=13 September 2013}}</ref>
On 19 March 2012, the Council of the EU adopted a general approach supporting the Commission's proposal to close the loopholes in the EU shark finning legislation by ensuring that all sharks were landed with their fins naturally attached without exception. It is believed that Spain and Portugal were the only EU Member States to raise objections to the Commission's proposal.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
On 6 June 2013, the Council of the EU completed the final step to close loopholes in the EU shark finning ban. By adopting a "fins naturally attached" policy without exception, the EU has now effectively ended the practice of shark finning by EU vessels.<ref name="HSI">{{cite web|url=http://www.hsi.org/world/europe/work/shark_finning/facts/shark_finning_Europe.html|title=Shark finning and the European Union|author=Humane Society International|author2=Europe|year=2013|accessdate=13 September 2013}}</ref>
==National restrictions==
===Australia=== Shark finning is not allowed in any [[tuna]] or [[billfish]] longline fishery, or in any Commonwealth fishery taking sharks. Fins must be landed attached, and additional regulations apply in some states or territories. In [[New South Wales]], sharks taken or any relevant portion of a shark taken may not be on board any vessel at any time (including after landing) without fins naturally attached.<ref>Fisheries Management Act 1994, s.8 Notification – Fishing Closure (Official Notices, 2 September 2011 NSW Government Gazette No. 86 Department of Primary Industries</ref>
====Imported products==== In Australia, the export and import of wildlife and wildlife products is regulated under Part 13A of the federal [[Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999]] (EPBC Act), which is administered by the [[Department of Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities]]. Regulation applies equally to individuals, commercial organisations and not-for-profit organisations. CITES Appendix II shark specimens cannot be legally imported into Australia for personal or commercial purposes unless: * The specimen is accompanied by a valid Australian CITES import permit (Australian import permits can be granted only if an overseas CITES export permit has been granted); or * The specimen is accompanied by a valid certificate issued by the overseas CITES management authority confirming that the specimen was obtained before the species was listed on CITES (pre-CITES certificate); or * The specimen is accompanied by an overseas CITES export permit or equivalent, is part of personal accompanied baggage and is intended for personal use and not for trade or sale.
No permits are required for the import of specimens obtained from shark species other than those listed above, however, to avoid seizure all products must be clearly labelled or have documentation certifying the species of origin.
===Canada=== Shark finning has been illegal in Canada since 1994, but importing fins from other regions without such regulations is allowed.<ref name=mississ-ban />
In late 2011, the city of [[Brantford, Ontario]] became the first city in Canada to pass new [[bylaw]]s to ban the possession, sale or consumption of shark fin products. In that medium-sized city in which no restaurants exist which serve shark fin, there was no opposition to the ban, which was largely symbolic. Nevertheless, a handful of cities soon followed, notably [[Toronto]], Calgary, [[Mississauga, Ontario|Mississauga]] and several others in [[Southern Ontario]]:
* [[Brantford, Ontario]] 11 to 0 vote<ref>{{cite news|first=Wency |last=Leung |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/food-and-wine/trends/trends-features/brantford-first-city-in-canada-to-ban-shark-fin/article2025124/ |title=Brantford first city in Canada to ban shark fin |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date=17 May 2011 |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> * [[Oakville, Ontario]] 7 to 0 vote<ref>{{cite web|last=Lem |first=Sharon |url=http://www.torontosun.com/2011/07/05/shark-fins-banned-in-oakville |title=Shark fins banned in Oakville | Toronto & GTA | News |publisher=Toronto Sun |date=5 July 2011 |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> * [[Mississauga, Ontario]] 11 to 0 vote<ref name=mississ-ban>{{cite web|url=http://www.mississauga.com/news/article/1220601--city-moving-on-shark-fin-ban |title=City moving on shark fin ban |publisher=Mississauga Article |date=6 October 2011 |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> (later repealed by Council on 8 May 2013)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www7.mississauga.ca/documents/agendas/committees/council/05_08_2013_Council_Minutes.pdf |title=Council Minutes May 8 2013 |publisher=mississauga.ca |date=22 May 2013 |accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mississauga.ca/portal/cityhall/pressreleases?paf_gear_id=9700020&itemId=1102110r&backUrl=%2Fportal%2Fcityhall%2Fpressreleases%3Fpaf_gear_id%3D9700020 |title=Mississauga Shark Fin By-law Repealed| publisher=mississauga.ca |date=10 May 2013 |accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> * [[Toronto]] 38 to 4 vote<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/story/2011/10/25/shark-fin-ban-vote.html |title=Toronto bans shark fin |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=25 October 2011 |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> (later overturned by court on 30 November 2012)<ref name=TorontoBanLifted /> * [[Newmarket, Ontario]] 8 to 1 vote<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.citytv.com/toronto/citynews/news/local/article/196307--newmarket-the-latest-municipality-to-ban-shark-fin |title=Newmarket the latest municipality to ban shark fin – CityNews |publisher=Citytv.com |date=27 March 2012 |accessdate=3 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617035143/http://www.citytv.com/toronto/citynews/news/local/article/196307--newmarket-the-latest-municipality-to-ban-shark-fin |archivedate=17 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * [[Calgary]] 13 to 2 vote<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/story/2012/07/16/calgary-shark-fin-ban.html|title=Calgary city council to draft shark fin ban bylaw|publisher=CBC|date=16 July 2012|accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref>
[[Markham, Ontario|Markham]] and [[Richmond Hill, Ontario|Richmond Hill]] opted not to bring forth the motion, suggesting that this issue is a federal matter. Chinese restaurants and businesses selling shark's fin opposed the ban, and in late 2011, suggested that they will challenge the by-laws before the courts once fines are imposed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yorkregion.com/news/article/1231469--richmond-hill-avoids-shark-fin-debate |title=Richmond Hill avoids shark fin debate |publisher=YorkRegion Article |date=25 October 2011 |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> When Toronto imposed steep fines, they did just that.
In late 2012, the [[Ontario Superior Court]] overturned Toronto's shark fin ban, ruling that the law as written was outside the powers of the city to impose without a "legitimate local purpose", and was therefore of "no force and effect." The judge accepted that the practice of shark finning was inhumane, but he did not agree with Toronto's justification of local purpose —– namely, that the consumption of shark fins may have an "adverse impact" on the health and safety of its residents and on the environmental well-being of the city.<ref name=TorontoBanLifted>{{cite news|last=Kari|first=Shannon|title=Ontario court overturns Toronto's shark fin ban|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/toronto/ontario-court-overturns-torontos-shark-fin-ban/article5881455/|accessdate=19 January 2013|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=30 November 2012}}</ref> Toronto has served legal notice that it plans to appeal the court ruling.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stewart|first=John|title=Is municipal shark fin ban dead in the water?|url=http://www.mississauga.com/news/article/1560843--is-municipal-shark-fin-ban-dead-in-the-water|accessdate=19 January 2013|newspaper=Metroland News|date=3 January 2013}}</ref>
On 1 December 2012, Ontario Superior Court Judge James Spence ruled that Toronto's ban was not valid. Members of Toronto's Chinese business community had also challenged that ban. Judge Spence had said the city does not have the power to enforce the ban. [[Toronto]]'s mayor [[Rob Ford]] in September 2012 believed the ban was not the cities responsibility and so did not support it at that time.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ontario judge rules Toronto's shark fin ban invalid|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/ontario-judge-rules-toronto-s-shark-fin-ban-invalid-1.1221802|work=CBC News Toronto|accessdate=1 December 2012}}</ref>
On 27 March 2013 a private members bill to ban shark fin imports into Canada failed in the [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]]. Shark finning was already illegal in Canadian waters, but there was no law to stop importing into Canada.<ref>{{cite web|title=Private member's bill pushing shark fin import ban fails|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/private-member-s-bill-pushing-shark-fin-import-ban-fails-1.1324003|work=CBC News Ottawa|accessdate=28 March 2013}}</ref> However, it would be restarted by Conservative Senate member [[Michael L. MacDonald]] in Bill S-238 which was passed by the Senate on October 23, 2018. That bill will now go to the House of Commons for further debate.<ref>{{cite web|title=Senate passes bill that would ban whale, dolphin captivity in Canada|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/tasker-whale-dolphin-captivity-canada-senate-bill-1.4876136|work=CBC News|accessdate=24 October 2018}}</ref>
On 8 May 2013 Calgary's City Council decided to wait until December 2013 and recommended leaning away from a total ban and look for ethical sources of shark products. Alderman John Mar said there will be more time to discuss and engage and to look for other options. The new wording in the bylaw was meant to ban the sale, distribution and trade of shark fins, but not ban the possession and consumption. Canada's city of Vancouver councillor [[Kerry Jang]] was at Calgary's council meeting and said that it was not a cultural thing, and that even China and the Chinese government decided to phase out all shark fins from state banquets. He also mentioned that the wordings of the bylaws in Calgary and Toronto, which face legal problems with municipal jurisdiction, are trying to ban possession and consumption, but that is hard to enforce and regulate.<ref>{{cite web|title=Calgary delays shark fin ban decision|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/calgary-delays-shark-fin-ban-decision-1.1306222|work=CBC News Calgary|accessdate=8 May 2013}}</ref>
On 27 May 2013, against the wishes of the Shark Fin Free Calgary organization, [[Calgary City Council]] overturned the ban. There were protests against the ban from Calgary's Chinese community, and [[Calgary]]'s city task force recommended against the ban. According to the article in The [[Calgary Herald]], Calgary's Mayor [[Naheed Nenshi]] never wanted a full ban, even though he had voted for the ban the previous year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Council shelves push for shark fin ban|url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/news/calgary/Council+shelves+push+shark/8440252/story.html|work=Calgary Herald|accessdate=28 May 2013}}</ref>

===Hong Kong=== [[File:IMG-20180615-WA0006.jpg|thumb|left|320px|Shark fin protestors at Maxim's HQ, Hong Kong 2018-06-15 also protesting re Starbucks giving their regional license to Maxims.]] [[File:Fedex anti shark fin protest 3 July 2016 Kennedy Town, Hong Kong.jpg|thumb|320px|Anti shark fin protestors at the FedEx depot in Hong Kong's Kennedy Town 3 July 2016]] The World Wide Fund for Nature on 8 March 2018 reported, "The volume of shark fin imported into Hong Kong has declined from 10,210 tonnes in 2007 to 4,979 tonnes in 2017, a drop of over 50 per cent."<ref name=wwfimp>[https://sharks.panda.org/news-blogs-updates/latest-news/hong-kong-shark-fin-imports-down-50 "Hong Kong shark fin imports down 50%" panda.org 8 March 2018]</ref> Protestors have targeted various brands with anti-shark fin demonstrations. After being targeted in a May 2016 protest at [[Hong Kong International Airport]],<ref name= scmpcat>[https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/1958732/cathay-pacific-targeted-shark-fin-protest-hong "Cathay Pacific targeted in shark fin protest at Hong Kong International Airport" Danny Lee, South China Morning Post, Sunday, 29 May, 2016]</ref> [[Cathay Pacific]] in June 2016 announced they would stop shipping shark fin.<ref name=physcat>[https://phys.org/news/2016-06-hong-kong-cathay-pacific-shark.html "Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific bans shark fin" phys.org 22 June 2018]</ref> [[Hong Kong Disneyland|Disneyland Hong Kong]] removed shark fin soup from its wedding banquet menu after international pressure from environmental groups, who threatened to boycott its parks worldwide despite the high demand for the delicacy.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2005/06/25/business/media/shark-soup-is-off-the-menu-at-hong-kong-disneyland.html Shark Soup Is Off the Menu at Hong Kong Disneyland], www.nytimes.com, 25.6. 2005</ref> [[The Peninsula Hotels|The Peninsula Hotel]] banned shark fin in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|last=Li |first=Zoe |url=http://www.cnngo.com/hong-kong/eat/peninsula-shark-fin-ban-491245 |title=The Peninsula Hotels group bans shark fin |publisher=CNNGo.com |date=22 November 2011 |accessdate=3 April 2012}}</ref> In April 2018 Shark fin protesters gatecrashed the opening of [[Shake Shack]] at the IFC in [[Hong Kong]]. This was due to Shake Shack partnering with [[Maxim's Caterers]] being Shake Shack's Hong Kong licensee.<ref name=protest1>[https://www.hongkongfp.com/2018/04/16/pictures-shark-fin-protesters-gatecrash-hong-kongs-shake-shack-burger-joint-pop/ "In Pictures: Shark fin protesters gatecrash Hong Kong’s Shake Shack burger joint pop-up" Tom Grundy, Hong Kong Free Press, 16 April 2018]</ref> Brand premises directly owned by Maxim's have been targeted in numerous protests.<ref name=maxabc>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-06-10/protesters-urge-hong-kong-restaurant-to-stop-selling-shark-fin/8607644 "Anti-shark fin soup protesters target famous Hong Kong restaurant Maxims Palace over product's sale" abc.net.au 10 Jun 2017]</ref><ref name=hkudemo>[http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/economy/article/2132856/shark-fin-protest-draws-50-activists-outside-hku-branch "https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/economy/article/2132856/shark-fin-protest-draws-50-activists-outside-hku-branch" Danny Lee, Rachel Leung, 10 February, 2018]</ref> On 15 June 2018 protestors directly targeted Maxim's headquarters in a demonstration that also highlighted Maxim's being a regional licensee for [[Starbucks]].<ref name=hkfpstarb>[https://www.hongkongfp.com/2018/06/14/animal-activists-take-aim-starbucks-claiming-licence-holder-maxims-continues-serve-shark-fin/ "Animal activists take aim at Starbucks, claiming licence holder Maxim’s continues to serve up shark fin" Jennifer Creey, Hong Kong Free Press, 14 June 2018]</ref><ref name=hkfpmaxhq>[https://www.hongkongfp.com/2018/06/16/pictures-animal-activists-protest-maxims-hq-continued-sale-shark-fin/ "In Pictures: Animal activists protest at Maxim’s HQ over their continued sale of shark fin" Jennifer Creery, Hong Kong Free Press, 16 June 2018]</ref>
===Taiwan=== Taiwan banned shark finning in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Taiwan to Establish Shark Finning Ban|url=https://news.yahoo.com/taiwan-establish-shark-finning-ban-193610255.html|accessdate=2 December 2011|newspaper=PR Newswire|date=21 October 2011}} {{dead link|date=December 2012}}</ref>
===Malaysia=== Malaysia was one of the top 10 importers and exporters of shark fins in the world between 2000 and 2009.<ref name="shaberycheek"/> The country caught 231,212 tonnes of sharks from 2002 to 2011, making it the eighth highest in the world and accounting for 2.9% of the global sharks caught during the same period.<ref name="shaberycheek"/>
In 2007, Malaysia's Natural Resources and Environment Ministry, [[Azmi Khalid]], banned shark's fin soup from official functions committing to the [[Malaysian Nature Society]] (for conservation of shark [[species]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/299995/1/.html |title=ChannelNewsAsia.com, Malaysian ministry bans shark's fin soup |publisher=Channelnewsasia.com |date=15 September 2007 |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> In 2012, the [[Sabah]] Tourism, Culture and Environment Minister proposed an amendment to the Fisheries Act that would give force to setting up a shark sanctuary zone in [[Semporna]] and other shark populated areas in Sabah. This ban was put on hold pending the Federal Government's decision on the issue. In 2015, Agriculture and Agro-based Industry Minister, [[Ahmad Shabery Cheek]], said that the ban of shark finning is "unnecessary" as the finning industry does not exist in Malaysia He went on further to say "Sharks are normally caught by accident when they enter the fish nets along with the other fishes."<ref name="shaberycheek">{{cite web|url=http://www.therakyatpost.com/news/2015/10/05/no-need-for-ban-on-shark-hunting-finning-industry-says-shabery-cheek/ |title=No need for ban on shark hunting, finning industry, says Shabery Cheek |publisher=The Rakyat Post |date=5 October 2015 |accessdate=5 October 2015}}</ref>
===New Zealand=== The great white sharks have been given full protection in the territorial waters of New Zealand<ref> {{cite web |url = http://beehive.govt.nz/release/full+protection+great+white+sharks+starts+today |title = Full protection for great white sharks starts today |last = Anderton |first = Jim |date = 1 April 2007 |publisher = New Zealand Government |accessdate = 27 August 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081016134240/http://beehive.govt.nz/release/full+protection+great+white+sharks+starts+today |archivedate = 16 October 2008 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> but shark finning is legal on other shark species if the shark is dead. The [[Royal Forest and Bird Protection Society of New Zealand]] are campaigning to raise awareness of shark finning<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.forestandbird.org.nz/Marine/SharksPage.asp |title=Save Our Sharks |publisher=[[Royal Forest and Bird Protection Society of New Zealand]] |accessdate=27 August 2008 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> and a number of [[foodies]] have fronted the campaign.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/4669469a19716.html |title=Foodies sign pledge against shark fin soup |date=27 August 2008 |publisher=NZPA |accessdate=27 August 2008 }}</ref>
At 10 November 2013, an announcement was made by the conservation minister proposing that shark finning will be outlawed in New Zealand waters.<ref>http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/shark-finning-outlawed-in-nz-5705963</ref>
===Palau=== In 2009, the Republic of Palau created the world's first [[shark sanctuary]]. It is illegal to catch sharks within Palau's [[EEZ]], which covers an area of {{convert|230000|sqmi|km2}}. This is an area about the size of France. President [[Johnson Toribiong]] also called for a ban on global shark finning, stating: "These creatures are being slaughtered and are perhaps at the brink of extinction unless we take positive action to protect them."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/8272508.stm "Palau pioneers 'shark sanctuary'"] ''BBC News'', 25 September 2009.</ref>
===Singapore=== Leading Singapore-based supermarket chain [[Cold Storage (supermarket)|Cold Storage]], has joined the [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] Singapore [[Sustainable seafood]] Group and agreed to stop selling all shark fin and shark products in its 42 outlets across the country. The supermarket is a subsidiary of [[Dairy Farm]], a leading pan-Asian food retailer that operates more than 5,300 outlets and employs some 80,000 people in the Asia-Pacific region. It is the first supermarket in Singapore to implement a no shark fins policy.<ref>[http://wwf.panda.org/wwf_news/?201825 "Leading Singaporean supermarket chain says "no" to shark fin"] ''WWF'', 30 September 2011</ref>
The largest supermarket chain in Singapore, [[NTUC Fairprice]] and [[hypermarket]] [[Carrefour]] will also be banning all shark fin products from its outlets before April 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Carrefour says no to shark's fin|url=http://sg.news.yahoo.com/ntuc-s--no-shark-s-fin--policy-to-kick-in-by-end-april.html|accessdate=4 April 2012|newspaper=Yahoo! Singapore|date=7 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=No shark's-fin products at FairPrice from April|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Latest%2BNews/Singapore/Story/A1Story20120106-320164.html|accessdate=4 April 2012|newspaper=AsiaOne|date=6 January 2012}}</ref>
===United States=== {{Update|section|date=December 2017}}
[[Bill Clinton]] signed the [[Shark Finning Prohibition Act of 2000]] (SFPA), which banned finning on any fishing vessel within United States territorial waters, and on all U.S.-flagged fishing vessels in international waters. Additionally, shark fins could not be imported into the United States without the associated carcass. In 1991, the percentage of sharks killed by U.S. longline fisheries in the Pacific Ocean for finning was approximately 3%. By 1998, that percentage had grown to 60%. Between 1991 and 1998, the number of sharks retained by the Hawaii-based swordfish and tuna longline fishery had increased from 2,289 to 60,857 annually, and by 1998, an estimated 98% of these sharks were killed for their fins.{{citation needed|date=January 2009}} [[File:Shark fins confiscated from King Diamond II.jpg|right|thumb|250px|The ''King Diamond II'' was seized in 2002 while carrying over {{convert|32|ST|MT|abbr=off|0}} of shark fins that were harvested from about 30,000 sharks.|alt=Small tied bales of flat gray objects, messily stacked underneath a translucent tentlike roof between white walls.]] In 2002, in an apparent early success in stopping the shark fin trade, the United States intercepted and seized the ''King Diamond II'', a U.S.-flagged, Hong Kong-based vessel bound for Guatemala. The vessel was carrying {{convert|64695|lb|ST t|abbr=off|1}} of baled shark fins – representing the fins of an estimated 30,000 sharks – making it the largest quantity of shark fins ever seized.<ref name="Science News post">{{cite web|last=Raloff|first=Janet|title=No Way to Make Soup—Thirty-two tons of contraband shark fins seized on the high seas|url=http://www.sciencenews.org/view/generic/id/3082/title/Food_for_Thought__No_Way_to_Make_Soup%2B%23151%3BThirty-two_tons_of_contraband_shark_fins_seized_on_the_high_seas|publisher=[[Science News]]|accessdate=25 March 2012}}</ref> This seizure was reversed in court six years later: in ''[[United States v. Approximately 64,695 Pounds of Shark Fins]]'', the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] [[holding (law)|held]] that the SFPA did not cover the seized fins in this case. Judge [[Stephen Reinhardt]] found that the ''King Diamond II'' did not meet the statute's definition of a fishing vessel, since it had merely bought the fins at sea and had not aided or assisted the vessels that had caught the sharks.<ref name="U.S. v. Shark Fins">{{Cite court |url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=10574858809426807872 |litigants=United States v. Approximately 64,695 Pounds of Shark Fins |vol=520 |reporter=F.3d |opinion=976 |pinpoint=979 |court=[[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|9th Cir.]] |date=2008}}</ref>
As a result, in January 2011, President [[Barack Obama]] signed the [[Shark Conservation Act]] into law to close the loopholes. Specifically, the new law prohibits any boat to carry shark fins without the corresponding number and weight of carcasses, and all sharks must be brought to port with their fins attached.<ref>{{cite news |date=21 December 2010 |accessdate=5 January 2011 |url=http://ecocentric.blogs.time.com/2010/12/21/a-happier-year-in-store-for-america%E2%80%99s-sharks/ |title=A Happier Year in Store for America's Sharks? |first1=Krista |last=Mahr |publisher=Time }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=5 January 2011 |accessdate=5 January 2011 |url=http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/136039-obama-signs-two-energyenvironment-bills-into-law |title=Obama signs two energy/environment bills into law |first1=Andrew |last=Restuccia |publisher=The Hill }}</ref>
In 2010, [[Hawaii]] became the first state to ban the possession, sale and distribution of shark fins. The law became effective on 1 July 2011.<ref>{{cite news |title= Hawaii: Shark Fin Soup Is Off the Menu |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/29/us/29brfs-SHARKFINSOUP_BRF.html |agency= [[Associated Press]] |newspaper= [[The New York Times]] |date= 29 May 2010 |page= A16 |accessdate= 20 June 2011 |quote= Gov. Linda Lingle signed a bill on Friday prohibiting the possession, sale, trade or distribution of shark fins, which are used in expensive Chinese dishes.}}</ref> Similar laws have been enacted in the states of [[Washington (state)|Washington]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Washington bans sale, trade of shark fins |publisher=Seattle Times|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/wash-bans-sale-trade-of-shark-fins/ |date= |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> [[Oregon]],<ref>[http://www.leg.state.or.us/11reg/pubs/hsemh.html Oregon House of Representatives bills of 2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007034403/http://www.leg.state.or.us/11reg/pubs/hsemh.html |date=7 October 2011 }} Oregon's shark fin bill was HB 2838 by Representative [[Brad Witt]]. Passed Senate unanimously, passed House 58 to 1. Signed into law by Governor [[John Kitzhaber]] on 16 June 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://data.oregon.gov/dataset/Bills-Signed-by-Governor-Kitzhaber/4aug-3v37/374 |title=Bills Signed by Oregon Governor Kitzhaber |publisher=Data.oregon.gov |date= |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> California,<ref name=harmon>{{cite web|last=Harmon |first=Steven |title=Gov. Jerry Brown signs bill banning shark fins in California |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19065609 |work=San Jose Mercury News |accessdate=10 October 2011 |date=8 October 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63o5QtaCv?url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19065609 |archivedate=9 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> the territory of [[Guam]]<ref>{{cite news |title= Guam Moves to Protect Sharks – Governor Calvo Signs Shark Fin Ban into Law in Guam |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/10/idUS23020+10-Mar-2011+PRN20110310 |agency= [[Thomson Reuters]] |date= 9 March 2011 |accessdate= 23 June 2011 |quote= ... Guam has now become the third place in the Pacific that has taken a definite stand against shark finning, the trade of fins and shark fin soup. |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111011082303/http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/10/idUS23020+10-Mar-2011+PRN20110310 |archivedate= 11 October 2011 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> and the [[Northern Mariana Islands|Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guammicronesiadivetravel.com/travelblog1/?p=1155 |title=Shark Fin Possession Bill Made Law Today in Guam |publisher=Guammicronesiadivetravel.com |date= |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> California governor [[Jerry Brown]] cited the cruelty of finning and potential threats to the environment and commercial fishing in signing the [[bill (proposed law)|bill]].<ref name=harmon/> Opponents charged the ban was [[Racial discrimination|discriminatory]] against [[Chinese American history|Chinese]], the main consumers of [[shark fin soup]], when federal laws already banned the practice of finning. Whole sharks would still be legally fished, but the fins could no longer be sold.<ref name=harmon/>
In 2012, legislators in the [[New York State Assembly]], including [[Grace Meng]], introduced a similar bill, which passed in 2013. While New York was not the only [[Eastern United States|Eastern]] state considering a ban, passage there would be significant since its Chinese American communities in [[Chinatown, Manhattan]] and [[Flushing, Queens|Flushing]] make New York the major importer of shark fins in the East. Meng admitted that while she loved shark fin soup, "it's important to be responsible citizens." Younger Chinese Americans in New York did not consider it an important part of their culture. "It's only the elderly who want it: when their grandkids get married, they want the most expensive stuff, like an emperor," said one waiter at a Chinese restaurant. Many businesses that sold fins had stopped placing new orders, expecting a ban would be passed.<ref name="NYT NY ban article">{{cite news|last=Rosenthal|first=Elisabeth|title=New York May Ban Shark Fin Sales, Following Other States|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/22/nyregion/bill-in-albany-would-ban-sale-of-shark-fins.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=22 February 2012|accessdate=25 March 2012}}</ref>
In April 2013, Maryland became the first state on the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] to enact a law against shark finning or the import of fins.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.humanesociety.org/news/press_releases/2013/05/maryland-bans-shark-fin-trade-050213.html |title=Maryland Becomes First State on East Coast to Ban Shark Fin Trade |publisher=The Humane Society of the United States |accessdate=2017-12-05 }}</ref> Texas, Illinois, Delaware, Rhode Island, and Massachusetts have also enacted bans, totaling 11 states.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.konbini.com/us/lifestyle/selling-shark-fins-crime-states-across-america/|title=Selling shark fins is now considered a crime in 11 states across America|last=Kirby|first=Matthew|date=2017-01-04|work=Konbini United States|access-date=2018-03-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://usa.oceana.org/press-releases/texas-becomes-10th-state-ban-trade-shark-fins|title=Texas Becomes 10th State to Ban Trade of Shark Fins|last=Vorpahl|first=Amelia|date=2015-06-22|work=Oceana USA|access-date=2018-03-16|language=en}}</ref>
[[File:Shark fin ban map US 2018.png|thumb|right|275px|Map of the United States showing states and territories that have banned the sale or possession of shark fins as of 2018 (shown in green)]]As of September 2018, 12 [[U.S. state]]s and 3 [[Territories of the United States|U.S. territories]] have banned the sale or possession of shark fins:<ref name="awi">https://awionline.org/content/restaurants-currently-offering-shark-fin-soup<br> ''Restaurants Currently Offering Shark Fin Soup''. Animal Welfare Institute. Retrieved September 4, 2018.</ref> {| | *{{flag|American Samoa}} *{{flag|California}} *{{flag|Delaware}} *{{flag|Guam}} *{{flag|Hawaii}} *{{flag|Illinois}} *{{flag|Maryland}} *{{flag|Massachusetts}} || *{{flag|Nevada}} *{{flag|New York}} *{{flag|Northern Mariana Islands}} *{{flag|Oregon}} *{{flag|Rhode Island}} *{{flag|Texas}} *{{flag|Washington}} |}
===United Nations=== In recent decades high demands and numerous forces of economic globalization has come together to create a true global mart. There has been a combination of growth and antifinning regulations that has led fishers to see sharks as a commercial species. This has unintentionally caused commercial species to be targeted rather than targeting more-valuable species like tuna and swordfish. However, the emergence of a new market for shark fins with addition to stricter regulations has all created a greater incentive for the full utilization of the shark. Now this is an important aspect to consider, as where antifinning and environmental groups can be successful in terms of decreasing the consumption and the practice of shark finning.<ref>http://www.fao.org/3/a-i4795e.pdf</ref>
==See also== {{Commons category}} * [[Pain in fish]] * [[Declawing of crabs]] * [[Shark fin trading in Costa Rica]] * [[Chinese imperial cuisine]] * [[Endangered sharks]], many sharks are endangered as a consequence of the market for shark fins

{{more footnotes|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox military conflict |conflict =Siege of Ascalon |partof =the [[Crusades]] |image = |caption = |date =25 January – 22 August 1153{{sfn|Lev|1991|p=104}} |place =[[Ashkelon]], [[Fatimid Caliphate]] |coordinates ={{coord|31|40|1.68|N|34|32|53.3|E|display=title}} |map_type = |map_relief = |latitude = |longitude = |map_size = |map_marksize = |map_caption = |map_label = |territory = |result =[[Crusades|Crusader]] victory, fall of Ascalon |status = |combatants_header = |combatant1 =[[File:Armoiries de Jérusalem.svg|18px]] [[Kingdom of Jerusalem]]
[[File:Cross of the Knights Templar.svg|border|18px]] [[Knights Templar]]
[[File:Cross of the Knights Hospitaller.svg|border|18px]] [[Knights Hospitaller]] |combatant2 =[[Fatimid Caliphate]] |commander1 =[[Baldwin III of Jerusalem]]
[[Bernard de Tremelay]] {{KIA}} |commander2 = |units1 = |units2 = |strength1 = |strength2 = |casualties1 = |casualties2 = |notes = |campaignbox ={{Campaignbox Fatimid-Crusader War}}
{{Campaignbox Crusades Battles}} }} The '''Siege of Ascalon''' took place in 1153, resulting in the capture of that [[Egypt]]ian fortress by the [[Crusade]]r [[Kingdom of Jerusalem]]. == Background == Ascalon was [[Fatimid]] Egypt's greatest and most important frontier fortress. The [[Battle of Ascalon]] was fought outside the city in 1099 in the aftermath of the [[First Crusade]] and the [[Siege of Jerusalem (1099)|fall of Jerusalem]] to the Crusaders. Although the crusaders were victorious, internal disputes in their camp allowed Ascalon to remain in Egyptian hands. Thereafter, the Fatimids were able to launch raids into the kingdom every year from this fortress, and the southern border of the crusader kingdom remained unstable. If this fortress fell, then the gateway to Egypt would be open. Therefore, the Fatimid garrison in Ascalon remained strong and large. After the failure of the [[Second Crusade]] in 1148, [[Conrad III of Germany]] attempted to besiege the fortress, but was forced to withdraw when no help was forthcoming from Jerusalem or other crusaders. Meanwhile, the territory to the east and north of Jerusalem was united under [[Nur ad-Din Zangi]], who ruled [[Mosul]] and [[Aleppo]] and brought [[Damascus]] under his influence after the Second Crusade. In 1149 Nur ad-Din defeated the [[Principality of Antioch]] at the [[Battle of Inab]]. Nur ad-Din was unable to overrun Antioch entirely, nor was he able to penetrate far into the Kingdom of Jerusalem, but likewise there was little Jerusalem could do in the north and the east with the whole area united under one strong ruler. The crusader kingdom would have to look towards Egypt if they wanted to expand. Around 1150, [[Baldwin III of Jerusalem]] rebuilt the [[Gaza City]], which at that point lay in ruins. The city was handed over to the [[Knights Templar]], and provided some defense against the continual raids from Ascalon, {{convert|10|mi|km}} to the northeast. Since the establishment of the kingdom, other fortresses had also been built to watch Ascalon. These were [[Ibelin (castle)|Ibelin]] (Yibneh) about {{convert|20|mi|km}} northeast of Ascalon near the coast, [[Blanchegarde]] (Tell es Safi) about {{convert|15|mi|km}} east-northeast, [[Beth Gibelin]] (Bait Jibrin) about {{convert|19|mi|km}} eastSmail, p 211 and [[Montgisard]] near Ramla {{convert|28|mi|km}} to the northeast. However, Jerusalem itself was soon divided by civil war. Baldwin III was the legal heir to the kingdom, but his mother [[Melisende of Jerusalem|Queen Melisende]] had been ruling as regent since 1143. In 1152 Baldwin finally demanded full control of the kingdom; after some brief fighting he was able to accomplish this goal. Later that year Baldwin also defeated a [[Seljuk Turks|Seljuk Turkish]] invasion of the Kingdom. Encouraged by these victories, Baldwin decided to make an assault on Ascalon in 1153. With the entire army of Jerusalem he marched to the fortress and began to destroy the surrounding [[orchard]]s in January. [[Patriarch Fulcher of Jerusalem|Patriarch Fulcher]] was also present, along with [[Raymond du Puy de Provence]] and [[Bernard de Tremelay]], the masters of the [[Knights Hospitaller|Hospitallers]] and Templars respectively, and all the other great barons of the kingdom, including [[Hugh of Ibelin]], [[Philip of Milly]], [[Humphrey II of Toron]], and [[Raynald of Châtillon]]. The siege was undertaken both by land and by sea, with the fleet commanded by Gerard of Sidon. The crusader force was also bolstered by a large group of pilgrims, who happened to be on their way to Jerusalem at the time. On the Fatimid side, the city was garrisoned by members of the local Kananiyya tribe, as well as a cavalry contingent from Cairo, some 400 to 600 strong, that was rotated into the city every six months.{{sfn|Lev|1991|pp=103, 126—127}} In response to the Crusader attack, the [[vizier]] [[Ibn as-Sallar]] began preparing reinforcements for the city in March, as well as a naval expedition.{{sfn|Lev|1991|pp=103–104}} The army set off and got as far as [[Bilbays]], while Ibn al-Sallar supervised the final preparations of the fleet, including a naval review and the payment of the crews. The army commanders at Bilbays, led by Ibn al-Sallar's stepson [[Abbas ibn Abi al-Futuh]], hatched a plot to kill the vizier, which was carried out on 3 April. The army returned to Cairo, where Abbas became vizier, leaving Ascalon largely to its fate.{{sfn|Lev|1991|p=104}}{{sfn|Daftary|1992|p=250}} The Fatimid fleet sailed to Ascalon and easily dispersed the weak Crusader squadron of 15 ships, but as the city's harbour was unsuitable for sustaining a fleet for long periods of time, it had to return to Egypt.{{sfn|Lev|1991|p=104}} [[Siege tower]]s were constructed, and for five months there were many skirmishes and victories and defeats on both sides. Ascalon was vast and virtually impenetrable; behind its massive walls and gates were twice as many defenders as there were besiegers outside, and there were supplies of food to last for years. In May the Egyptian fleet arrived to resupply the city; Gerard of Sidon's little fleet could do nothing to stop them. However, a setback for Ascalon occurred in August when the besieged tried to burn down one of the crusader siege towers; the wind pushed the fire back against their own walls, causing a large section to collapse. According to [[William of Tyre]], knights of the Order rushed through the breach without Baldwin's knowledge while [[Bernard de Tremelay]] and about forty of his Templars were killed by the larger Egyptian garrison. Their bodies were displayed on the ramparts and their heads were sent to the caliph in Cairo. In a differing account by a [[Damascus|Damascene]] chronicler in the city, the breach of the wall is simply mentioned as a precursor to the fall of the city; he makes no mention of the incident with the Templars. Because of William of Tyre's dislike of the Order, and the wildly inaccurate news that reached Europe during the crusades, his account must be treated with caution; but regardless of which account is believed, Bernard was killed during the fighting. By now the crusaders were becoming fatigued and it was suggested that they abandon the siege. The Hospitallers and the Patriarch, however, convinced the king that they were on the verge of victory. Three days later another assault was made, and another entrance was forced. After bitter fighting the city fell to the crusaders on August 19, and the fortress was formally surrendered to them three days later. The citizens were allowed to leave in peace; most fled back to Egypt. == Aftermath == Ascalon was turned into a [[diocese]] directly under the [[Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem|Patriarch of Jerusalem]], although in earlier times it had been a suffragan of the Bishop of [[Bethlehem]]. The city's mosque was reconsecrated as a church. The city was also added to the County of Jaffa, which was already held by Baldwin III's brother [[Amalric I of Jerusalem|Amalric]]. The double [[County of Jaffa and Ascalon]] later became the most important crusader seigneury, held either as an [[apanage]] to the crown or granted to influential barons. The fall of Ascalon contributed to the downfall of Fatimid Egypt. Amalric succeeded his brother as king of Jerusalem in 1162, and throughout the 1160s led numerous expeditions from Ascalon into Egypt. These [[Crusader invasions of Egypt]] failed to bring that country under Amalric's control. == References == {{reflist|30em}} == Sources == *''The Damascus Chronicle of the Crusaders, extracted and translated from the Chronicle of [[Ibn al-Qalanisi]]''. Edited and translated by H. A. R. Gibb. London, 1932. *[[William of Tyre]]. ''A History of Deeds Done Beyond the Sea''. Edited and translated by E. A. Babcock and A. C. Krey. [[Columbia University Press]], 1943. * {{cite book|last=Daftary|first=Farhad|authorlink=Farhad Daftary|title=The Isma'ilis: Their History and Doctrines|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|year=1992|isbn=978-0-521-42974-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cSO9zh61AGEC|ref=harv}} * {{cite book | last = Lev | first = Yaacov | title = State and Society in Fatimid Egypt | year = 1991 | location = Leiden | publisher = Brill | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=I2LwgIL_bpEC | isbn = 9789004093447 | ref=harv }} *[[Steven Runciman]], ''A History of the Crusades, vol. II: The Kingdom of Jerusalem and the Frankish East, 1100-1187''. [[Cambridge University Press]], 1952. *[[Malcolm Barber]], ''The New Knighthood'' (Great Britain; Cambridge University Press, 1994), p. 74-75 * Smail, R. C. ''Crusading Warfare 1097-1193.'' New York: Barnes & Noble Books, (1956) 1995. {{ISBN|1-56619-769-4}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ascalon 1153, Siege of}} [[Category:1153 in Asia]] [[Category:12th century in the Fatimid Caliphate]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1153]] [[Category:Battles involving Egypt]] [[Category:Sieges involving the Fatimid Caliphate]] [[Category:Sieges involving the Kingdom of Jerusalem|Ascalon]] [[Category:Battles involving the Knights Templar|Ascalon]] [[Category:Sieges involving the Knights Hospitaller|Ascalon]] [[Category:Period post Second Crusade]]
